important_phrase: Heavy showers improved drought conditions in much of the District
Residential real estate contacts noted that existing and new home sales were flat to slightly up from a year ago, and home prices improved modestly
Business contacts continued to describe a tightening labor market, and difficulties finding workers with specialized skills persisted
Lending remained competitive, and some community depository institutions cited difficulties in competing with loan structures and terms offered by larger institutions
Finished inventory levels were reported to be rising, while supplier delivery times increased slightly
Most builders and brokers reported that home sales were flat to slightly up relative to one year earlier, although reports on the level of buyer traffic were mixed
The outlook among retailers for the upcoming holiday season remains optimistic
Reports from First District business contacts suggest that activity is expanding at a somewhat slower pace currently than was the case six weeks ago
Reports on bill and pay rates are mixed, ranging from flat to increases of 10 percent year-over-year
Inventories are mixed
According to First District contacts, office leasing activity remains strong in Boston and light in Hartford
Given these trends, contacts express uncertainty about 2016
The condition of the District's corn and soybean crops improved further in October and early November
Wge pressures remained limited
A staffing firm continued to report moderate wage increases
Financial market volatility increased slightly, but remained lower than in recent months
Overall, though, the pace of hiring slowed notably, particularly for non-auto-related manufacturers, and hiring plans remained modest
Commercial real estate activity continued to increase moderately
New and used light vehicle sales remained strong, and leasing activity increased noticeably
Investment in mid-stream projects is expanding slightly, while downstream investment in refinery projects is strong
Reports indicated a tightening in labor markets
Consumer lending expanded modestly over the period, although some banks noted a downturn in auto lending
Overall, input and finished-goods prices were steady
However, they see this slowing as a short-term event
Vendor and shelf prices were fairly stable, other than declines in gasoline
Domestic demand for grains and cattle remained solid but export demand was weak
Price pressures remained subdued and employment held steady or increased
Employment in most industries held steady or increased
Loan demand grew at a slighter softer pace over the last six weeks
Demand for high-tech manufacturing picked up slightly, although concerns about weakness in the global economy continued to weigh on producers
Despite some slowing, sales of low- to mid-priced new homes remained strong
Contacts expect steady sales through year end
Farming conditions weakened further since the last survey period as agricultural commodity prices remained relatively low
Energy activity continued to decline moderately, and farm income weakened further
Transportation input prices increased slightly while selling prices continued to decline
Finally, most respondents reported stable deposit levels
Nondurable goods production remained positive
Inventories increased slightly, and home sales were expected to slow in the winter months due largely to seasonal factors
Restaurant sales weakened further but were higher than a year ago, with contacts expecting moderate improvements in the months ahead
The Ninth District economy grew moderately overall since the last report
Commercial construction expanded at a strong pace since the last report
Consumer spending was moderate
Rain improved conditions in the Dallas District, where domestic demand for grains and cattle was solid, but export demand was weak
On balance, housing markets improved at a moderate pace since the previous Beige Book, and home prices increased modestly
Wge pressures were generally stable to increasing
Dallas noted some tightening of standards in response to slowly declining loan quality among energy sector loans
Manufacturing in the Richmond, Atlanta and Dallas Districts grew modestly, with reports that new orders and production levels increased slightly
In the Richmond District, residential real estate increased moderately
Boston-area business travel remained strong, although leisure travel decreased a bit
Consumer spending has been mixed but somewhat weaker, on balance, while tourism has remained sluggish
Small to medium sized banks in the District report mixed demand for loans
The labor market has been mixed but still fairly strong in recent weeks
Residential construction has been steady
Some improvement was also noted in sales of used vehicles
General retailers reported that sales slowed to a more modest pace
Overall, contacts continued to report only slight upward wage pressures, although some contacts continued to report difficulties filling highly technical positions
Auto loans and home equity lines grew moderately, as did credit card balances
Third District service-sector firms reported a moderate pace of growth--a slight improvement from the prior period
Builders continued to note difficulties managing labor costs as subcontractors remained cautious about expanding to meet demand
An outlets operator reported moderate sales growth, which is slower than the norm for their value-oriented stores
Agribusiness softened since the last report
Retail price increases slowed, while prices at other services firms rose at a moderately faster rate
According to our most recent surveys, employment softened at manufacturing firms but rose modestly at services firms
Since our previous Beige Book, lending activity picked up modestly in the District

On balance,
manufacturing grew modestly since the previous report
Commercial real estate activity increased moderately
Retail prices rose more slowly since the last report
Output in the agriculture and resource sector expanded modestly over the reporting period
Agricultural activity edged up modestly
Overall price inflation appeared to tick up slightly on balance
Lending activity grew modestly over the reporting period
Deliveries of commercial aircraft were up slightly from the same period a year prior, but new orders were significantly lower
Demand for new residential units remains high, with one contact highlighting growing backlogs for planned projects
Retail sales grew at a moderate pace; however, a few contacts noted that sales had slowed somewhat from the summer
Because of relatively low production levels and low crop prices, industry contacts mostly have a negative outlook for farm income
Banking conditions remain stable, as loan demand remains relatively strong, particularly for commercial and industrial loans
By sector, most manufacturing contacts reported their prices to customers have remained unchanged or are slightly lower, whereas construction contacts noted increasing prices
Loan delinquencies were unchanged to slightly lower for all loan categories, and the creditworthiness of applicants was unchanged
Manufacturing activity has increased since our previous report
Residential real estate activity expanded at a faster pace than in the previous report
General retail has continued to grow modestly since the previous report
